summary: The goal of the present study was to characterize acute oxidative damage in ocular structure and retinal function after exposure to spaceflight . The goal was to evaluate the efficacy of an antioxidant in reducing spaceflight-induced changes in the retina .

Environmental, radiotherapy, and pathological conditions can induce the production of a high level of unstable oxygen species . Efforts have been made to develop drugs with therapeutic potential . Practical application has been disappointing due to complications such as short half-lives, low reaction rate constants, lack of cellular uptake, and hypersensitivity reactions .

The IOP was measured from a randomly selected left or right eye of each mouse before launch and shortly after landing . The post-flight saline and BuOE-treated FLT groups showed a decreasing trend in IOP, compared to pre-flight measurements .
The response is lower with increased flash intensity in the post-flight group compared to the pre-flight response . Each point represents the mean ± SEM (n = 8)

The amplitude of the a- and b-wave that reflected an average response to all flash intensities in the post-flight group was significantly reduced for both saline and BuOE-treated mice . The amplitude was also reduced for the GC group . The response is similar between pre- and post-GC measurements .  The post-flight comparison of the retina light sensitivity to the b-wave in saline or BuOE-treated flight (FLT) and habitat ground control (GC) groups . Bars represent the mean ± SEM (n = 8) Bars represent mean ± SE (n)
The 4-hydroxynonenal marker for oxidative damage was evaluated in the retina . Enhanced 4-HNE staining was seen in cone photoreceptors, retinal INL, and GCL in the spaceflight group .

Figure 10 shows a decrease of 20% in cone photoreceptor density in the spaceflight saline mice . FLT mice did not gain weight after the flight as was observed for GC group .  The data were consistent with previous observations and showed no significant differences between pre-flight groups, or between flight and control groups . This indicates that a 35-day space mission may have a limited impact on irreversible IOP changes .
Most human retina disorders are detected by attenuation of amplitude . Study shows spaceflight-induced retinal functional change may occur as a result of photoreceptor damage and cellular death .

Study documented increased oxidative damage with 4-HNE staining, a biomarker for lipid peroxidation in cone photoreceptors, retinal INL, and GCL . Redox-active metalloporphyrin antioxidants have been shown to be effective in protecting against radiation-induced ocular damage .
Mouse research-18 (RR-18) mission for 35 days aboard the ISS . Mouse kept at an ambient temperature of 26–28 °C with a 12 h light/

Mice were provided NASA Nutrient-upgraded Rodent Food Bar (NuRFB) and autoclaved deionized water ad libitum . BuOE at 1 mg/kg (0.2 mL) was administrated subcutaneously 7 days prior to the flight launch and weekly aboard the ISS . Mice returned to Earth via SpaceX’s Dragon capsule
